title: Sunday Notebook: UNTUCKit unfolds at Town Center
content: UNTUCKit, a clothing store featuring casual apparel and shirts that don’t need to be tucked in, has opened its first store in Jacksonville.    The UNTUCKit store that opened Thursday in St. Johns Town Center is the chain’s 30th. The business is in a 1,500-square-foot building at the Town Center, a company news release said.    While UNTUCKit initially focused on button-down shirts designed to hang over the belt line, the company has added T-shirts, polo shirts, sports jackets and boy’s and women’s lines of clothing.    Drew Dixon    Parking app for reserved spaces    A Florida-based mobile application that helps drivers reserve parking spaces at shopping malls and parking garages is now being offered in Jacksonville.    MyPark was implemented in Jacksonville at St. Johns Town Center on Friday, a company news release said. Motorists traveling to the outdoor mall can now reserve a space to park when they download the MyPark app on their Android and iPhone devices.    The cost to park is $3 for the first two hours and $3 per hour after that.    There are 17 MyPark spaces at the Town Center, in areas near the Apple store, Dillard’s, Ted’s Montana Grill and DSW Designer Shoe Warehouse.    Drew Dixon    Medical building changes hands    A 7,600-square-foot medical office building in the Belfort Oaks Village development near St. Vincent’s Medical Center Southside has been sold for $1.45 million to an investor who plans to occupy a vacant unit and lease back 4,000 square feet to the seller.    Carmen Mantay of NAI Hallmark, who brokered the sale, said, “The medical office building market in Jacksonville has become stronger due to inventory absorption and low supply of this kind of property. In fact, I have experienced a significant increase in demand from medical buyers the past year."    In public records, the buyer of the property is identified as Devaux Real Estate Holdings LLC.    Clay Zeigler    Jacksonville medical firm nabs patent    Jacksonville-based Medtronic Xomed, a medical apparatus firm, received a patent from the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office for a surgical instrument motor. The device increases power for surgical instruments and decreases heat generation, a patent office summary said.    The co-inventors are Manfred K. Luedi of Jacksonville; Vikram A. Garadi of Fort Worth, Texas; Thierry A. Bieler of Echichens, Switzerland; and Christian R. Koechli of Yvonand, Switzerland.    J&J secures patent for ophthalmic devices    Johnson & Johnson Vision Care of Jacksonville secured a patent for devices used in ophthalmology procedures.    The patent issued by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office provides for innovations in sealing and encapsulating components used on ophthalmology instruments. Some of those devices include lenses, a patent office summary said.    The co-inventors are Randall B. Pugh and Adam Toner, both of Jacksonville;l James Daniel Riall of St. Johns County; Daniel B. Otts of Fruit Cove; Sharika Snook of St. Augustine; and Frederick A. Flitsch, New Windsor, N.Y.    Drew Dixon    PERMITS    989 Imeson Park Blvd., addition to existing fabrication shop for Star Fabricators LLC., $3 million, 34,847 square feet. Stellar Group Inc.    Construction of two new Racetrac gas stations and convenience stores, combined $1.62 million, for a combined 11,000 square feet. One station is at 2009 Mayport Road and the other is at 5004 Gate Parkway. Venture Construction Co.    117 Duval St. W., renovation of existing food service room at City Hall café, $147,610, 996 square feet. Auld & White Constructors LLC.    800 Prudential Drive, demolition of four-story parking garage for Southern Baptist Hospital, $800,000. J.B. Coxwell Contracting Inc.    4201 Beflort Road, renovation of existing room for power circuitry at Ascension Health Resource, $153,517, 400 square feet. Gilbane Building Co.    9317 Atlantic Blvd., alterations and improvements to Ashley Furniture, $343,000, 35,520 square feet. Mibarev Development 1 LLC.    1 Imeson Park Blvd., interior buildout of existing office space at GIV Imeson LLC, $365,195. Dav Lin Interior Contractors.    12608 Beach Blvd., demolition and new construction at Fifth Third Bank, $446,382, 3,008 square feet. Marand Builders Inc.    SALES    Andrew and Vanessa Shaw paid $1.88 million for a 7,724-square-foot home at 1875 Avondale Circle. The house was built in 1927 and last sold for $2.2 million in 2013.    Jeremy Foley paid $1.25 million for a 3,133-square-foot home at 335 Ninth St., Atlantic Beach. The house was built in 2004 and last sold for $899,900 in 2012.    Permits and Sales are compiled by Drew Dixon.
